key_insight: The paper presents an end-to-end framework that conditions de novo small‑molecule generation on patient bulk transcriptomes and uses metaheuristic assembly plus target‑driven filtering to produce personalized drug candidates for AML.
problem_solved: Bridges the gap between heterogeneous patient-specific transcriptomic profiles and actionable small‑molecule discovery for Acute Myeloid Leukemia, addressing the need for precision therapies when mutation‑specific options are unavailable.
method: Profile patient bulk RNA‑seq (TCGA‑LAML) to identify dysregulated genes/pathways and patient‑specific targets (e.g., coexpression/DGE analysis such as WGCNA).
Use a metaheuristic assembly algorithm to generate de novo molecular structures conditioned on transcriptome‑derived targets and objective functions.
Apply target‑driven filtering and ranking (binding‑likelihood, pathway relevance, drug‑likeness and toxicity proxies) to prioritize personalized candidate compounds.
impact: Delivers a reproducible computational template for integrating omics into generative drug design, enabling AI/ML practitioners to build and evaluate end‑to‑end pipelines that produce clinically relevant, patient‑conditioned candidates.
visual_elements: Pipeline flowchart: patient RNA‑seq → target identification → metaheuristic molecule assembly → target‑driven filtering → prioritized candidates
Heatmap or cluster map of patient‑level dysregulated genes/pathways (showing heterogeneity across AML samples)
Schematic of metaheuristic assembly moves (e.g., fragment addition/removal, scoring) with example molecule evolution
Bar/stacked chart ranking top candidate molecules by combined score (target match, predicted binding, drug‑likeness)
paper_title: Transcriptome-Conditioned Personalized De Novo Drug Generation for AML Using Metaheuristic Assembly and Target-Driven Filtering
paper_authors: Abdullah G. Elafifi, Basma Mamdouh, Mariam Hanafy, Muhammed Alaa Eldin, Yosef Khaled
